skills.name: Identify non-unit fractions when part of a shape
Calculate unit fractions of an amount
Calculate non-unit fractions of an amount
Calculate the whole amount, given a fraction of the amount

explanations.A: There are 4 circles out of a total of 11 shapes, so we can write that the fraction of circles is 4/11.
explanations.B: This is how many circles there are, but what is this as a fraction of all the shapes?
explanations.C: Almost. We need to have the number of circles as a fraction of all the shapes. How many shapes are there in total?
explanations.D: You are really close. Remember the number of circles is the numerator

explanations.A: You are really close. Remember the number of triangles is the numerator
explanations.B: This is how many triangles there are, but what is this as a fraction of all the shapes?
explanations.C: Almost. We need to have the number of triangles as a fraction of all the shapes. How many shapes are there in total?
explanations.D: There are 7 triangles out of a total of 15 shapes, so we can write that the fraction of triangles is 7/15.

explanations.A: Not quite. We don't subtract 3, we want to split the 24 up into 3 equal parts
explanations.B: This is 3 x 24. We want to split the 24 up into 3 equal parts
explanations.C: Imagine 24, the whole amount, split into 3 equal parts. Each of those parts represents ⅓ and has a value of 24 ÷ 3 = 8.
explanations.D: Not quite, this is a quarter of 24. Just check your division

explanations.A: Not quite. We don't subtract 6, we want to split the 24 up into 6 equal parts
explanations.B: Imagine 24, the whole amount, split into 6 equal parts. Each of those parts represents ⅙ and has a value of 24 ÷ 6 = 4.
explanations.C: This is 6 x 24. We want to split the 24 up into 6 equal parts
explanations.D: Not quite, this is an eighth of 24. Just check your division

explanations.B: I think you have mixed up the operations. The denominator tells us how many parts to split it into, and the numerator is how many parts we have
explanations.C: This is 2/5. Just be careful with your multiplication
explanations.D: Imagine 30, the whole amount, split into 5 equal parts. Each of those parts represents ⅕ and has a value of 30 ÷ 5 = 6, and so 3 parts is 3 × 6 = 18.

explanations.A: This is ⅙, so what would 5 of these be?
explanations.B: Imagine 30, the whole amount, split into 6 equal parts. Each of those parts represents ⅙ and has a value of 30 ÷ 6 = 5, and so 5 parts is 5 × 5 = 25.
explanations.C: This is 4/6. Just check your multiplication
explanations.D: I think you have mixed up the operations. The denominator tells us how many parts to split it into, and the numerator is how many parts we have

explanations.A: 1/4 of 60 is 15. Try using a bar model where 1 of the 4 parts represents 20. What is the whole bar worth?
explanations.B: I think you added 4 by mistake. Try using a bar model where 1 of the 4 parts represents 20. What is the whole bar worth?
explanations.C: You have found 1/4 of 20 rather than the number 20 is a quarter of. Try using a bar model where 1 of the 4 parts represents 20. What is the whole bar worth?
explanations.D: Imagine ★, the whole amount, being split into 4 equal parts. The question tells us that each of those parts is equal to 20. As there are 4 of them, we can write ★ = 4 × 20 = 80.

explanations.A: I think you are almost there. Just check whether you carried when doing the multiplication.
explanations.B: You have found 1/3 of 27 rather than the number 27 is a third of. Try using a bar model where 1 of the 3 parts represents 27. What is the whole bar worth?
explanations.C: Imagine ★, the whole amount, being split into 3 equal parts. The question tells us that each of those parts is equal to 27. As there are 3 of them, we can write ★ = 3 × 27 = 81.
explanations.D: I think you added 3 by mistake. Try using a bar model where 1 of the 3 parts represents 27. What is the whole bar worth?

explanations.A: This is ⅔ of 36, not the number 36 is 2 thirds of. Try using a bar model where 2 of the 3 parts represents 36. What is the whole bar worth?
explanations.B: This is 1/3 of 36, not the number 36 is 2 thirds of. Try using a bar model where 2 of the 3 parts represents 36. What is the whole bar worth?
explanations.C: Imagine ★, the whole amount, being split into 3 equal parts. The question tells us that 2 of those parts is equal to 36. This means 1 part = 36 ÷ 2 = 18. As we are interested in 3 parts, the whole amount, we can write ★ = 3 × 18 = 54.
explanations.D: Almost, this would be true if 36 was 1/3 of the amount. How would this affect your answer?

explanations.A: Imagine ★, the whole amount, being split into 6 equal parts. The question tells us that 5 of those parts is equal to 75. This means 1 part = 75 ÷ 5 = 15. As we are interested in 6 parts, the whole amount, we can write ★ = 6 × 15= 90.
explanations.B: Almost, this would be true if 75 was 1/6 of the amount. How would this affect your answer?
explanations.C: This is 5/6 of 75, not the number 75 is 5 sixths of. Try using a bar model where 5 of the 6 parts represents 75. What is the whole bar worth?
explanations.D: This is 1/6 of 75, not the number 75 is 5 sixths of. Try using a bar model where 5 of the 6 parts represents 75. What is the whole bar worth?
